Almost forgot to respond.
I used to do this a lot, reddit and twitter were my go-to.
Eventually, reddit got more and more censor heavy. I'd get banned from subs and not bother to make a new account. So I stopped reading comment threads on things I knew I would argue with. /r/politics is just... a disaster. for example. Occasionally i would type up a comment and then just not post it because, it really doesn't matter whatever this persons response will be, and I can avoid myself a stupid headache.

Now, if I see a redditor saying something really questionable, I just look at their account and see where they post and how frequently. Most people are genuinely normal, with a variety of interests, just a different opinion. Some people spend a lot of time in certain flavors of crazy. Many people just have way too much time, so they spend it by arguing on reddit. They aren't serious and you are not going to win or change their mind.

Engaging with comments can be a healthy and intellectually stimulating experience in moderation, so I understand the appeal, but if you must, choose your battles carefully. But my advice for stopping is to stay away, and if you must, look with passing interest. Remember, all of this is excessively fleeting and 99% of it is valueless.

Meanwhile, on twitter, I got banned there too. Although my "death threat" (using navy seals copypasta) ban was a misunderstanding, the only regret I have from it is that it pushed me to 4chan. On twitter, I'd argue, and looking at the things i was posting before my ban, I was more toxic and heated than I should ever be. It draws you in. Now and then, ill look at random tweets and look around, and often time, someone is posting something astoundingly stupid that needs calling out, but its not worth it. Maybe they're trolling and not even serious.

Recognize the uselessness of the situation. Get banned. Stop browsing inflammatory content. Delete before you post. Care less. GL

com:
This week is my finals week.
I would have had my first one yesterday, and I completely missed it.
I thought it would be Wednesday. I didn't even bother to double check.
So I just slept over it.
I feel like this is just a symptom of a larger trend in my life where I either intentionally or subconsciously harm myself.
First there is actual self-harm. I'm 21 and have been cutting since I was 17. I no longer do it in visible places. I have also added other methods, such as burning myself, not eating for days, not sleeping for days, etc.
Then there are the more subtle things. You see, I'm a lazy person. If I could choose what to do with my life, I would be a NEET shut-in until I could no longer take it and then kms.
My family really wants me to have a career though, so they wanted to do absolutely everything for it, like get in a club, get an internship, get a research, and I did all those things.
I got kicked from the club because I never did my activities. None of the club members became a friend.
The research is going nowhere so I'm just kind of keeping distance from it. I'll probably have to explain myself to my professor at some point.
I'm going to lose my internship because I failed this semester. It was my only source of income and honestly more fun than uni, so I'm kind of really hating myself over this one.
In my graduation itself, well... I don't study. At all. I was able to be top student in high school and in my first two years of uni but I guess my ego and pride just got too overblown. I actually feel like I'm lowering myself by studying.
There's a few more examples of this trend but I think these are the big ones.
It's very clear to me where this will end if I keep taking this path.
So how do I stop it?

The next day a pigeon was dead in my driveway.
I help people, but it does nothing. Zero sum acceptance on their behalf. I thought I could try emulating Christ, offering my existence to others - turns out it depends on the magnanimity of your own soul in their eyes... I am already dust. Just a few words out of my mouth, or a few seconds of watching the way my eyes (fail to) read them, and they know that I was made with only a single foot in this world. Not even a dud, but a kind of simulacrum of a person. They turn their brains off when they talk to me to keep themselves sane. Exposure to my true self, which is my mere self, my lame and dull self, would be enough to turn them into shadows. They use the weight of time on my rung - that which takes me so long to do normal things - that prevents me from experiencing intimate connection. I don't ask, I don't plead. What can I possibly do?

last_replies.com:
>>27906563
Yeah I have had this problem since I was young. Wasted my teens and 20s doing this. Trust me the cure is doing stuff.

Nowadays I let myself daydream cause at least its distracts me from overthinking real world bullshit out of my control. I guess thats all daydreaming ever is but at least I am now conscious of it enough to control it.

The doing creative stuff or reading and mental stimulating hobbies (example tabletop games might be something you get into that leads to friends at least) help to let out the restless imagination. But the more mental meditative habits build your ability to redirect from restless daydreaming to more restful creative hobbies so do try both. Also exercise and lifting. Lifting helped me in that it gave me guilt free time to daydream but it also distracted me from daydreaming as I got more focused on why the fuck isnt my form right? If you can daydream well enough while doing some exercise thats a great way to get it out too. Biking and hiking are my favorite ways. Swimming in the summer is great to do.

Sometimes you cant force stop the daydreaming but you can force yourself to do some menial exercise or do the dishes while daydreaming. Makes the tasks easier. Almost makes them fun and makes you less guilty about time wasted daydreaming.

Dont waste too much daydreaming time inert is all.

im an empath and i struggle with seeing other people upset or in stress. if i see someone at work have something bad happen to them or even a football player on TV (e.g harry kane missing a penalty in the world cup), i feel like shit as i vivdly feel exactly what others feel on a deep level. it impedes on my every day life and even when im in my free time, my mind is consumed by others emotions

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27904399
Every suffering is relative. Get a life worth suffering for and you’ll quickly forget about others. It’s a part of maturity to be able to focus your caring and ignore the world’s suffering. Care for yoursel, your family, your friends, and your lovers - that’s all and in that order.

Once you’ve been screwed over enough by people you once empathized with, you will see that most people deserve their suffering.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>27904399
You being an empath isn't the issue here, you can understand the pain of others without feeling like shit about it. Heck, there are dark empaths - people who are deeply in tune with emotions of others but revel in the pain they cause.

The issue at hand is that you get easily emotional when witnessing the pain of others. The advice I'd give is fairly similar to those who get emotional of witnessing their own failures - Understand that pain is a natural part of life, but most of the time it's only a big deal if you make it so. Becoming frustrated with or wallowing in pain will damage you way more than the pain itself. Missing a shot in a football game? Unfortunate but not unbearable. It doesn't damage or scar you physically, you can still play in the future and hit other shots, it doesn't ruin any valuable relationships... it's hardly anything tragic.

Learn to separate tragedy from pain. Pain isn't evil. Through it we learn that putting our hand on a stove is a very bad thing. Through failures and mistakes we learn.
